race.name: Tour de Gap
race.tagline: Mississippi rolling hills gravel in Fulton.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling northeast Mississippi hills. Moderate elevation with rural scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional MS event. Rolling hills terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Tour de Gap is a regional event in Fulton, northeast Mississippi. The rolling hills terrain offers moderate climbing with rural scenery, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Fulton provides moderate access. It's a solid regional event for Mississippi cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Mississippi gravel race with rolling hills terrain. Worth it for Mississippi cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Mississippi rolling hills gravel in Fulton.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Mississippi and want a local rolling hills event‚Äîyes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Cohutta, Southern Cross. For similar regional events: other MS gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Fulton has limited lodging. Tupelo has more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Mississippi hills gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Mississippi rolling hills gravel in Fulton.

non_negotiables.why: Mississippi rolling hills require sustained effort.
MS spring/fall means heat and humidity are likely.

topics.heat: Racing in MS heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Mississippi rolling hills gravel in Fulton.

logistics.explanation: Friday packet pickup at Biketown and day-of registration at 6:15 a.m. show basic organization. The 10:45 a.m. cutoff at 40 miles creates course management complexity, but reever notes riders came "from all over Texas and some from Colorado and even Mexico," suggesting the setup handles multi-state logistics adequately.

length.explanation: The 100K at 62.5 miles hits solid gravel distance territory with multiple bailout options. Cutoff times give 5.5 hours from start to course closure at 1:00 p.m., creating reasonable pressure without being punitive for the distance. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Reever calls it "a very hilly course--definitely designed for an upright" after riding recumbent and hitting over 40 mph on descents. The Callahan Divide creates rolling challenge through South Taylor County backroads, but this reads more like power climbing than technical terrain navigation. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The "challenging hills of the Callahan Divide" provide enough climbing that reever averaged 18.6 mph in 2015 while winner Oscar Salazar hit 24.47 mph in 2024. The descents allow 40+ mph speeds, indicating meaningful elevation changes without being mountainous. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 91¬∞F and lows of 73¬∞F, with a 68% chance of rain on any given day. Late July in central Texas creates the heat challenge that defines this event more than the terrain. The 7:30 a.m. start acknowledges brutal summer conditions, but you're still finishing in Texas midday heat. Weather survival becomes part of the race equation. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Central Texas hill country means sea level elevation with zero altitude impact on performance. Buffalo Gap sits in typical Texas terrain that won't affect anyone's breathing or pacing strategies. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through "cool centuries-old live oak trees" at Buffalo Gap and tackling South Taylor County backroads creates scenic character. The Old Guy Bicycle Blog author sought "peace, fitness, grit, redemption" here, but generous cutoffs and multiple distances lean organized touring over wilderness exploration.

prestige.explanation: 42 editions makes this a Texas institution, but calling yourself 'THE classic Midsummer Texas Ride' doesn't make it nationally relevant. It sells out, which means local demand, but zero mention of pro fields or serious racing pedigree in the search results. Regional respect, not gravel scene credibility.

race_quality.explanation: Three distance options and organized start times show planning, while "exceptional volunteer support and well-stocked rest stops" according to Wheel Brothers indicates solid execution. The 10:45 a.m. checkpoint system manages course closure logistics effectively for a regional event.

experience.explanation: Starting under centuries-old live oaks at Old Settlers Reunion Grounds creates atmosphere, with swag raffles and lunch service extending the day beyond just racing. Breakfast vendor availability and the charitable mission supporting West Texas Rehabilitation Center add community purpose to the cycling.

community.explanation: Four decades of continuous operation proves local buy-in, and selling out the 2025 edition shows people keep coming back. Friday packet pickup at Biketown and benefiting local nonprofits like PMCM demonstrates community integration. Not flashy, but authentic small-town cycling culture.

field_depth.explanation: Reever finished 30th overall and 8th in his 50-59 age group in 2015, while 2024 winner Oscar Salazar averaged 24.47 mph over 62.5 hilly miles. Solid regional racing depth with age group prizes, but the generous cutoffs indicate recreational participation focus. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Free kids entry, breakfast vendor service, lunch provision, and swag raffles extend value beyond the race entry. Supporting West Texas Rehabilitation Center's healthcare mission adds purpose, while the event's 42-year sustainability suggests reasonable pricing for what's delivered.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Buffalo Gap sits 13 miles from Abilene for lodging access, with small-town Texas typically offering reasonable accommodation costs. The suggestion to visit Abilene Zoo indicates affordable family weekend options, keeping total trip expenses manageable for a Texas location. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Tour de Gap gravel race Fulton

videos.title: How Do Tour De France Riders Climb So Fast?
videos.description:
Ever wondered how Tour de France riders conquer brutal climbs at incredible speeds? Dan breaks down the key factors, comparing his efforts to a record-setting climb by Tadej Pogacar. Discover the critical role of power-to-weight, the benefits of drafting, and optimal pacing. PLUS, the surprising biomechanical technique and the importance of precise fuelling...

‚è±Ô∏è Timestamps ‚è±Ô∏è
0:00 - Introduction: how fast do they really climb? 
0:50 - The power-to-weight ratio explained 
1:17 - Drafting
1:46 - Gearing
2:11 - Pacing 
2:38 - Positioning & recovery strategies
2:58 - Fuelling
3:18 - Biomechanics
4:04 - Conclusion

The Global Cycling Network (GCN) is the largest online cycling channel in the world, bringing together a global community of road cyclists to celebrate everything that‚Äôs great about the world of cycling.

Our videos bring fans compelling daily content including expert tutorials, techniques, training, racing, cutting-edge bike tech, unparalleled behind the scenes event coverage, humour,  entertainment, and more.

Presented by ex-pro riders, GCN offers a uniquely qualified insight into the world of cycling, and most importantly it‚Äôs fuelled by our passionate and enthusiastic fans ‚Äì everyone who makes up the GCN community. We also bring the latest and greatest tech to your attention, showcase the best places in the world to ride and get exclusive access to events and races.

videos.transcript:
How did tour to France riders climb up
mountains so fast? The best pros can
average 25 km per hour or 15 mph up some
of the most brutal climbs in the world?
Is it just that they are fitter or is
there more to it? Before we get on to
the reasons why they're so fast, one of
which I think is really going to
surprise you, we wanted to show you
exactly how fast they are. We are midway
up the Kodal Lamadon in southern France.
This is me riding at the power I can
sustain for the entire 13 km climb which
is about 280 W. And then this is me
riding at the speed that threetime tour
to France champion Ted Pagata was riding
here when he set the record on this
climb. It's quite a big difference.
[Music]
The biggest determinant in climbing
speed is the power you produce versus
the weight of you and your equipment.
The more powerful you are and or the
lighter you are, the faster you will go.
The best climbers in the tour front have
a very high sustainable power and they
don't weigh very much either. Currently,
a power to weight of almost 7 watts per
kilo of body weight is needed to stick
with the very best in the key mountains.
They don't do it all on their own
though. Even on climbs, there will be a
benefit to sheltering from the air
behind teammates or other riders. For
example, the record speed at the C of
Galibier held by Paga is 27 km/h despite
the 5 12% average gradients. At that
speed, drafting is still going to offer
a significant power saving versus riding
into the wind yourself.
To France riders will also pay close
attention to their gears. Most will
maintain a high cadence of over 90
revolutions per minute. This allows them
to respond easier to any accelerations
in a group, but more importantly, it
reduces the fatigue to the muscles. The
power is the same, but torque is
reduced. It's like doing more sets but
with less weight in the gym.
Correct pacing is another vital tool in
mountains. Most amateurs will start
climbs way too fast and fade later.
Whereas the best tour of France riders
will stay within their limits, allowing
them to attack later on. They often use
power meters to gauge their efforts and
they know when to go fast and when to
take it easy. They also have an
incredible ability to recover from very
hard efforts whilst still climbing.
On shorter climbs, positioning going
into them can make a big difference as
to how fast you go up them. Start at or
near the front and you'll be able to
carry your momentum from the flat. Start
too far back and you might well find
yourself having to slow down or even
stop as the pelon tries to filter into a
narrower road.
Fueling strategy is a big consideration
for Tour to France cyclists. They will
consume up to 150 gram of carbohydrates
per hour and they've trained their
bodies to be able to absorb and use it.
This allows them to produce a similar
amount of power at the end of a long
gruelling stage as they can when they're
fresh at the start.
So those are the key points. But is
there anything less obvious that to
France riders are using to climb faster?
Yes. Biomechanics.
Some riders, including Tad Pagatcha, are
now pushing their saddle further
forwards and tilting it slightly down so
that their knees are vertically over the
pedals when they're climbing gradients
over 6%.
This can be described as pre-rotating,
effectively meaning that their saddle is
horizontal whilst the bike is angled
upwards with the gradient. The theory
goes that you get a better transfer of
power in that position whilst reducing
pressure behind the bottom bracket. It
might not work for everyone, but it's
certainly something that riders have
been experimenting with in recent times.
So, there you have it. The key
ingredient for tour France riders to go
that fast on mountains is a high
sustainable power and a reasonably low
weight. However, there is more that goes
into it than that. Not every rider with
the same power to weight ratio is able
to go up to the front mountains at the
same speed. Hope you've enjoyed this
video. If you have, please click on the
thumbs up button just down below. And if
you're yet to subscribe to GCN, there's
a button down below for that, too.

videos.title: Tom Pidcock - Top 5 WOW moments
videos.description:
The British cyclist tom pidcock is an incredible talent with incredible results. His bike handling skills are also among the best in the pro peloton. These skills have allowed him o win some of the biggest races in pro cycling. Now we are going to have a look at his 5 most impressive victories.

1 alp duez 
Pidcock used his incredible descending skills to bridge the gap to the breakaway on stage 12 of the tour de France. Then on the legendary climb  the Alp d‚ÄôHuez he went solo dropping the likes of chris froome to take the stage win. He won on the legendary climb by 40 seconds joining the likes of Geraint Thomas as a British winner on Alp d‚ÄôHuez

2 Cyclocross world championships
Once again pidcock showed his supreme bike handling skills by winning the cyclocross world championships. He looked comfortable and calm throughout and won this title at the age of only 22 years old. He won with a huge gap and nobody seemed to be able to challenge him. 

3 Olympic mountain bike
Pidcock won gold at the Tokyo 2020 Oylimpics in the mountain bike race. He beat the best mountain bike riders in the world showing that he can dominate in all 3 of the disciplines he chooses. The Oylimpics which he stated as being ‚Äòbigger than cycling‚Äô is definitely a highlight in his palmares.

4 Mountain bike world cup 
The first time we saw pidcock prove himself in elite level mountain biking was at the world cup race in nove mesto in 2021. He rode to an impressive and dominant victory again with time to spare. He beat the likes of Mathieu van der poel. Pidcock once again proved his ability on the mountain bike winning the world cup race in nove mesto. He beat the likes of Mathieu van der Poel in this exciting race.

5 La Fl√®che Braban√ßonne
He won the world tour classic La Fl√®che Braban√ßonne in exciting fashion after outsprinting Wout van Aert. Wout van Aert is a bigger rider with an impressive sprint so it was a very strong result from pidcock to be able to beat him to the line. This result also shows Pidcocks potential as a classics rider and we hope to see him contesting tour of flanders or liege bastonge liege one day

videos.title: Jonas Vingegaard DROPS Tadej Pogacar On Mont Ventoux
videos.description:
Watch more Tour de France videos: https://flosports.link/3jRBFNj
Danish rider Jonas Vingegaard of the Jumbo-Visma team attacked and dropped the race leader yellow jersey Tadej Pogacar of UAE Team Emirates on the slopes of Mont Ventoux on stage 11 of the 2021 Tour de France.

videos.title: Low Gap Grasshopper Gravel Guide (4K)
videos.description:
Gravel Bike California gets in on the adrenaline of the Grasshopper Adventure Series traveling out to Ukiah to take in the mixed surface of Low Gap: https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/low-gap-gravel-guide

Gravel Bike California Shop:
https://gravelbikecalifornia.threadless.com/

Check out our friends:
Grasshopper Adventure Series: https://grasshopperadventureseries.com/

Support Gravel Bike California on Patreon:
https://www.patreon.com/gravelbikecalifornia

Find more routes on our map of Gravel Guides across California:
https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/california-gravel-guides/

Follow us on:
https://www.instagram.com/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.facebook.com/groups/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.strava.com/clubs/gravelbikecalifornia

Route file:
https://ridewithgps.com/routes/38516363

0:00 - 0:48 Intro
0:48 - 2:36 Low Gap & Grasshopper Background
2:36 - 4:04 Course Fly-By
4:04 - 6:14 Start & Orr Springs Climb
6:14 - 8:08 Descent & Chase Pace
8:08 - 10:52 Low Gap Rollers & Climb
10:52 - 12:12 Ripping down Low Gap descent
12:12 - 13:46 After Party
